Package me.wobblyyyy.rlibx.input

Class InputDevice

java.lang.Object
me.wobblyyyy.rlibx.input.InputDevice
public class InputDevice
extends java.lang.Object
A generic type of input device that's designed to work with everything out of the box, with very little configuration.

Although controllers are nice and all, going up a step and using an input device expands the horizons of robot input. Simply using a controller class and nothing else makes it so that only a joystick can control the values of a motor's power or something like that.

By using a more generic and abstract InputDevice, we no longer need to worry about controller mishaps or mismatches. We have input channels, and each of these input channels accomplishes a single goal, and do so pretty well.

Input devices function by using an array of length 100 that stores data that pertains to... well, input. Examples include:

  • Color sensors.
  • Touch sensors.
  • Controller inputs.
  • Limit switches.
... you get the point - there's a lot of stuff you can put on a single input device.

The function of a class, such as this one, might seem to be a bit of a mystery. Why would you possibly use a more complex implementation of input when you can simply use... well, a simpler version? In this case, sticking with Controller would have been way more simple to implement.

However, this isn't a simple FTC and FRC library - this is much more of a robotics as a whole library. Robotics as a whole isn't only operated with controllers. Creating a separate class, a more abstract and generic class, allows us to interlock with many, many, many different input devices, compared to just two types of controllers.

InputDevices rely on the inputs HashMap to keep track of input values. The design philosophy behind the InputDevice class was to centralize all things related to robot input, thus making it incredibly difficult to get lost on what isn't working and why not.

For a common user, or a user who just wants to get a controller to work, regardless of anything else, InputDevice elements are just extra abstractions on top of the already rather uncomfortable Controller class. However, when it comes to managing things like multiple streams of input, sensors, encoders, controllers, etc - using an InputDevice might start to seem like a more appealing option.

Since:
0.1.0
Author:
Colin Robertson

  • Field Details

    • inputs

      private volatile java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,​java.lang.Object> inputs
      A HashMap that stores all of the useful information that's needed to manage multiple inputs at the same time.

      Although this HashMap does support the use of Objects as values, meaning you can technically store whatever you'd like here, I'd like to say quickly that the intention of this class is to provide simple inputs. Not outputs. Not products. Not points. If a primitive value can't encapsulate whatever you're attempting to do, you're almost certainly trying to store way too much information in the input device you're working with.

      A string key is used to track down different objects that are stored in the hash map from different locations in the codebase.

      The values stored in the HashMap are all notated in Object form. These values can easily be converted into doubles, integers, strings, etc.

      See Also:
      getInt(String), getDouble(String), getString(String), getObject(String), getBoolean(String), set(String, Object), setAll(HashMap), setMultiple(HashMap)

  • Constructor Details

    • InputDevice

      public InputDevice()
      Create a new InputDevice.

  • Method Details

    • set

      public void set​(java.lang.String key, java.lang.Object value)
      Set a given input key to have a certain value.

      This only sets a single key - not multiple keys. If you'd like to set multiple keys at once, or import a HashMap and set it as the current input stream, you can feel free to do so with some other methods.

      Parameters:
      key - the key that should be set.
      value - the value that the key should hold.
      See Also:
      inputs, setAll(HashMap), setMultiple(HashMap)

    • setAll

      public void setAll​(java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,​java.lang.Object> inputs)
      Set the inputs HashMap to an entirely new HashMap that's passed as a parameter to this method call.

      This method will reset the entire HashMap and replace it with whatever HashMap you provided as a parameter to this method.

      Parameters:
      inputs - the new HashMap that should replace the existing inputs HashMap.
      See Also:
      inputs, set(String, Object), setMultiple(HashMap)

    • setMultiple

      public void setMultiple​(java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,​java.lang.Object> inputs)
      Set multiple input channels to given values at the same time.

      Unlike the setAll(HashMap) method, this method does not clear the original HashMap when adding values.

      Keys that are already contained within the HashMap will be overwritten by any new values that you put in here - just something to keep in the back of your head.

      Parameters:
      inputs - a HashMap of String and Object pairs that will be added to the existing input HashMap.
      See Also:
      inputs, set(String, Object), setAll(HashMap)

    • getInt

      public int getInt​(java.lang.String key)
      Get an integer value from the HashMap of input streams.
      Parameters:
      key - the key to query.
      Returns:
      a value, based on the query key.
      See Also:
      inputs, getDouble(String), getString(String), getObject(String), getBoolean(String)

    • getObject

      public java.lang.Object getObject​(java.lang.String key)
      Get an object value from the HashMap of input streams.

      This method isn't particularly useful unless you cast the object that's stored in the HashMap into a more usable form of object. If you're attempting to get one of the following:

      • String
      • Double
      • Boolean
      • Integer
      ... methods for those casts already exist and are linked in the @see tags down below. If you're storing a custom object in the HashMap, you can cast it however you'd like.

      Parameters:
      key - the key to query.
      Returns:
      a value, based on the query key.
      See Also:
      inputs, getInt(String), getDouble(String), getString(String), getBoolean(String)

    • getInputs

      public java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,​java.lang.Object> getInputs()
      Get the input HashMap, which can then be used to observe or modify the state.

      It's advisable that you don't directly modify the HashMap, but rather, you modify it through some of the setter methods provided in the InputDevice class.

      Returns:
      the input HashMap.
      See Also:
      inputs, set(String, Object), setAll(HashMap), setMultiple(HashMap)

    • getClonedInputs

      public java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,​java.lang.Object> getClonedInputs()
      Get a cloned copy of the inputs HashMap. Unlike simply copying the HashMap, deep cloning it entirely separates the objects and values.

      If you would prefer to access the HashMap directly, without the use of a clone as a sort of proxy, you can use the method named getInputs(), which will return the HashMap used directly inside of the InputDevice class.

      Returns:
      a newly deep cloned version of the inputs HashMap.
      See Also:
      inputs, getInputs()
